Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Broadcast address
b. Multicast address
c. IP address
d. MAC address
e. Unicast address
LLM Explanation: Broadcast and multicast addresses are used in Ethernet to send a single frame that is delivered to multiple devices on a LAN. A broadcast address (FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF) sends the frame to all devices, while a multicast address sends the frame to a specific group of devices that have subscribed to that multicast group. The other options - IP address, MAC address, and unicast address - identify a single device and are used for one-to-one communication.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CD
b. CSMA/CA
c. TCP/IP
d. TCP/UDP
LLM Explanation: CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection) is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision. When a collision is detected, both devices stop transmitting, wait a random amount of time, and then retry the transmission.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/5241-csma-cd.html']

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard that defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling is 1000BASE-T. The '1000' in the standard name indicates the data rate of 1000 Mbps, which is equivalent to 1 Gbps (Gigabit per second). 10BASE-T and 100BASE-T are standards for 10 Mbps and 100 Mbps Ethernet, respectively, while '1' is not a valid Ethernet standard designation.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Working Group, http://www.ieee802.org/3/']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The preamble field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet frame allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks. It consists of a 56-bit pattern of alternating 1s and 0s that enables bit synchronization. The preamble is followed by the Start Frame Delimiter (SFD) field, which signals the start of the frame.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet']

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Source
b. Destination
c. Unicast
d. Broadcast
LLM Explanation: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the destination IP address is in a different subnet than the host. When a host needs to communicate with a device on a different network, it forwards the packets to its default gateway, which then routes the packets to the appropriate network.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 12: IP Addressing and Subnetting', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol in the TCP/IP model. It is used for sending and receiving email messages between servers. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and IP (Internet Protocol) reside in the transport and network layers, respectively, while Ethernet is a data link layer protocol.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: The Transport layer of the TCP/IP model is responsible for providing host-to-host communication services for applications. The two main protocols that reside in this layer are TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP (User Datagram Protocol). TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented transmission of data segments, while UDP provides a connectionless datagram service. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol, Ethernet is a data link layer protocol, and IP (Internet Protocol) resides in the Internet layer of the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 3: Fundamentals of TCP/IP Transport and Applications)', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: The Internet Protocol (IP) resides in the Internet layer of the TCP/IP architecture model. IP is responsible for addressing hosts and routing datagrams (packets) from a source host to the destination host across one or more IP networks.
URLs: ['Kurose, J. F., & Ross, K. W. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. J. (2011). Computer Networks (5th Edition). Prentice Hall.', 'IETF RFC 791 - Internet Protocol (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc791)']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet is a protocol that resides in the Data Link and Physical layers of the TCP/IP architecture. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol, TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a transport layer protocol, and IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer protocol.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. ping
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. DNS
LLM Explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) is used by a device to learn the MAC address of another device on the same network when it knows the IP address of that device. When a PC needs to communicate with another device on the local network, it checks its ARP cache for the MAC address associated with the IP. If not found, it broadcasts an ARP request to all devices on the network asking 'Who has this IP address?'. The device with that IP responds with its MAC address, which the requesting PC then stores in its ARP cache for future use.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 5: Fundamentals of IPv4 Addressing and Routing', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13718-5.html']

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and PC
b. Switch and PC
c. Hub and switch
d. Router and hub
LLM Explanation: A straight-through Ethernet cable is used when connecting devices of different types, such as a host to a switch or a router to a PC. In the given choices, a router connecting to a PC and a switch connecting to a PC would require straight-through cables. Hubs and switches are similar devices, so they would use a crossover cable when directly connected to each other.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/21223-cable-connection-21223.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. TCP
b. HTTP
c. Ethernet
d. PPP
e. SMTP
f. HTTPS
LLM Explanation: The data-link layer protocols in the TCP/IP model are responsible for delivering data over a physical network link. From the given options, Ethernet and PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) are examples of data-link layer protocols. Ethernet is widely used in local area networks (LANs), while PPP is used for point-to-point connections, such as dial-up internet access. TCP, HTTP, SMTP, and HTTPS are higher-layer protocols that operate at the transport layer (TCP) or application layer (HTTP, SMTP, HTTPS) of the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
c. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
d. Forwarding IP packets based on a packetâ€™s destination IP address
LLM Explanation: The main functions of a routing protocol are to learn routes from neighboring routers and advertise known routes to those neighbors. Routing protocols enable routers to dynamically share routing information, allowing them to learn about remote networks and determine the best paths to reach those networks. Routers then use this information to populate their routing tables. Directly connected routes are learned through interface configuration rather than routing protocols. Packet forwarding is a separate function performed by routers based on the information in their routing tables, but is not a direct function of routing protocols themselves.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 15: IP Routing in the LAN', 'Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Routing Dynamically - https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2180210&seqNum=7']

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When you enter a hostname like www.examsdigest.com in a web browser, your computer does not directly send an IP packet with that hostname as the destination IP address. Instead, it first uses the Domain Name System (DNS) to resolve the hostname to the corresponding IP address of the web server hosting the website. Once the IP address is obtained, your computer then sends the IP packet to that resolved IP address.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 1: Introduction to TCP/IP Networking', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/domain-name-system-dns/5735-dns-overview.html']

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Multicast
c. Unicast
d. MAC
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to transmit data to every node on a local network segment. It allows a single packet to be sent to all devices on the network simultaneously, rather than sending individual copies to each recipient. Broadcast addresses are typically used for network discovery, address resolution, and distributing routing information.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html', 'https://www.networkworld.com/article/3588315/what-is-a-broadcast-address-and-how-is-it-used.html']

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. UDP
b. HTTP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is the correct answer. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP are the two most commonly used transport layer protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite. While TCP is connection-oriented and provides reliable data delivery, UDP is connectionless and provides unreliable data delivery. HTTP, DNS, and SMTP are application layer protocols that rely on TCP or UDP for transport.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens (Addison-Wesley Professional)']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the Ethernet frame trailer provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine if the frame experienced transmission errors. The sending device calculates a Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) value based on the frame contents and appends it to the end of the frame in the FCS field. The receiving device recalculates the CRC and compares it to the FCS value. If they match, the frame is considered error-free. If they differ, the frame contained errors and is discarded.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet']
